nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Late afternoon at the pickup point. One backpack, one tired child, and two different worlds of rules.

The child shuffles toward you and blurts out, loud enough for the co-parent to hear:

“At Dad’s/Mom’s I can eat in the living room. Here I can’t do anything.”

You feel both pairs of adult eyes flick to each other for a split second.

choices.label: First, connect with the child and park the adult conflict for later.
Answer defensively in front of everyone: “That’s not true, you have lots of freedom here.”
Half-joke: “Different homes, different rules, kiddo,” and quickly change the subject.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
The co-parent adjusts their bag and steps a little closer.

“We’ve talked about this,” they say, trying to sound neutral. “They’re allowed to relax a bit at my place. It doesn’t have to be so strict all the time.”

There’s a choice to make: do you have this conversation right here, or do you move it somewhere calmer?

choices.label: Suggest a later talk: “Let’s get them settled first, then you and I can sync on rules.”
Compare households in front of the child.
Say nothing and end the exchange as quickly as possible.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Later, at home, the backpack is on the floor and the child is half-watching cartoons.

You notice little frictions everywhere: shoes, snacks, screen time.

It hits you: you and the co-parent have never really named which rules must match and which can safely differ.

choices.label: Decide to list the “non-negotiable” rules you want to align.
Tell yourself, “It’s pointless, they’ll never agree,” and drop the idea.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Act 1 closes with a simple truth:

The child is not keeping score on who has the “better” rules.
They’re trying to understand how to be one kid in two different systems.

The question now is whether the adults are willing to give them a clearer map.

choices.label: Move into Act 2 – adult sync on rules.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
A few days later, you and the co-parent are on a call. No child in earshot this time.

They sigh. “Look, they’re already under enough stress. I don’t want to fight about whether they can eat on the couch.”

This might be the moment to separate comfort rules from safety rules.

choices.label: Start by validating: “I agree, they are under stress. Can we pick a few rules to match so life feels less confusing?”
Lead with criticism: “You’re too lenient, that’s the whole problem.”
Stay vague: “Yeah, it’s complicated,” and keep things fuzzy.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
You pull up a quick list on your phone or a scrap of paper.

You jot down:
• Sleep time
• Homework
• Screens
• Food / snacks

The co-parent adds: “And how we talk about each other’s houses.”

choices.label: Sort the list into two columns: “must match” vs “can differ safely.”
Argue item by item without any shared framework.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Slowly, some shape appears:

You both agree that sleep and basic safety should be similar.
You can live with different snack rules and different “tidy up” styles.

The hardest part is how each of you talks about the other house in front of the child.

choices.label: Propose a simple shared line: “Both homes have rules to keep you safe, even if they look a bit different.”
Leave that part undefined: “We’ll just improvise as we go.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Act 2 doesn’t end with perfect alignment, but something important has shifted:

The rules are no longer a secret power struggle.
They’re items on a list that both of you can see and adjust over time.

choices.label: Move into Act 3 – giving the child a clearer map.

nodes.speaker: Teacher
nodes.text:
A week later, a teacher quietly pulls you aside at school pickup.

“They mentioned they’re worried about ‘getting in trouble’ for doing things differently at each house,” the teacher says. “They seem a bit on edge about making mistakes.”

choices.label: Thank the teacher and decide to talk with the child using the new shared language.
Minimize it: “They’re fine, we’re just going through a phase.”

nodes.speaker: Child
nodes.text:
At home, the child hovers in the doorway.

“Is it bad if I forget whose rules are whose?” they ask quietly.

You can feel how much they want a simple, steady answer.

choices.label: Use the shared sentence: “Both homes have rules to keep you safe; we’ll remind you, you don’t have to remember everything alone.”
Respond with pressure: “You’re old enough to remember. You have to keep track.”
Half comfort, half confusion: “Just do your best; it’s complicated.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Later that night, as they fall asleep, you notice their shoulders soften just a little.

Different rules still exist.
But the story around those rules has changed from “don’t mess up” to “the adults will guide you.”

choices.label: Close the scene and return to the scenario menu.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
This scene doesn’t magically unify two households.

Instead, it offers a more realistic win:

• a shortlist of rules that truly need to match,
• fewer casual comparisons of “who is stricter,”
• and a child who hears one steady message about safety across both homes.

You can replay the scene making different choices to feel how trust, tension, and child stress shift when the rules stay hidden versus when you bring them into the open.

acts.title: Act 3 – Giving the Child a Map
